choices.text: Stratum Spinosum is underdeveloped in Very Low Birth Weight infants in the initial 7 Days.
Icthyosis Vulgaris is due to the Deficiency of Filaggrin Protein which is found in Stratum Basale
The Malpighian Layer of the Epidermis includes both Stratum Basale & Stratum Granulosum as a unit.
Skin, Hairs, Nails, the Subcutaneous Tissue below the Skin & assorted Glands constitute the Integumentary System.

questions.text: Identify the True statement among the following?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Skin, Hairs, Nails, the Subcutaneous Tissue below the Skin & assorted Glands constitute the Integumentary System.

 

Option D:

 

  • Integumentary system is made up of Skin, hairs, nails, the subcutaneous tissue below the skin & assorted glands.
     
  • The most important function of the integumentary system is the protection against external damage.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A:

 

  • In the first seven days after birth, the stratum corneum (NOT Stratum spinosum) of very low birth weight infants is underdeveloped.
  • In preterm infants, the stratum corneum is permeable & becomes like the adult & full-term infant after 2-3 weeks of post-natal maturation.
     
  • The layers of the epidermis begin to form from the bottom up. As a result, the Stratum basale / Stratum germinativum forms first and the stratum corneum forms last.

 

Option B:

 

  • In icthyosis vulgaris there is deficiency of filaggrin protein. They are found in the keratohyaline granules of stratum granulosum (NOT Stratum basale) in the form of Profilaggrin (made of filaggrin monomers)
     
  • Profilaggrin undergoes proteolytic processing to yield individual filaggrin monomers that bind & aggregate keratin bundles & intermediate filaments between the stratumgranulosum & corneum to form the epidermal barrier of the skin.
     

 

Option C:

 

  • The Malpighian layer is named after Marcello Malpighi.
     
  • The Malpighian layer of the epidermis includes both stratum basale & stratum spinosum (NOT stratum granulosum) as a unit.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Understand that the integumentary system includes the skin, hair, nails, subcutaneous tissue, and associated glands, and identify the correct layers and proteins associated with specific functions and pathologies within the skin.

 

Ref: Rooks textbook of dermatology- 9th Edition: Volume 1 Chapter 2, Page no 2.2, 2.5, 2.7

Online resources: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC2721001/

https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/23248884/

choices.text: The Stratum Corneum, also known as the Horny Layer, consists of Cells without Nucleus & hence does not divide.
Granules of Eleidin are present in the Stratum Lucidum.
Odland Bodies are present in Stratum Basale
The Superficial Vascular Plexus of Skin is present below the Papillary Dermis.

questions.text: Identify the FALSE statement among the following?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Odland Bodies are present in Stratum Basale

 

Option C: Odland Bodies (Lamellar Bodies or Keratinosomes /Membrane Coating Granules):

 

  • Located in upper stratum spinosum and stratum granulosum (NOT Stratum basale)
  • Discharge lipid components for barrier function and intercellular cohesion.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Stratum Corneum: (Horny layer)

 

  • Composed of non-nucleated cells that don't divide.
  • Barrier function: It stops fluids from the body from leaking into the environment and stops environmental microbes from entering the body.
  • Changes during keratinocyte ascent:
  1. Loss of nucleus,
  2. Size increase,
  3. Shape flattening,
  4. Dehydration,
  5. Loss of metabolic activity.

 

Option B: Stratum Lucidum (Clear Cell Layer): (sandwiched between the granulosum and corneum)

 

  • Found in thick skin of palms and soles.
  • Contains eleidin granules, giving it the translucent appearance.
  • Abundance of keratin filaments and eleidin granules.
  • These cells could be considered transition cells because they are still nucleated.

 

Option D:

 

  • Below the papillary dermis is the skin's superficial vascular plexus.
  • The vascular supply in the dermis is abundant (unlike the epidermis which is avascular). The Dermis can be separated into papillary dermis (upper 1/10) & Reticular Dermis (lower 9/10)
  • The Deep Vascular Plexus is present below the reticular dermis, and the superficial vascular plexus is present between the papillary and reticular dermis (Subpapillary Plexus).

 

  • Reactive units of skin. The Superficial Reactive Unit (SRU) comprises the Epidermis (E), the Junction zone (J), and the papillary body (PB, or papillary dermis) with the superficial microvascular plexus. The Dermal Reactive Unit (DRU) consists of the Reticular Dermis (RD) and the Deep Dermal Microvascular Plexus (DVP). The subcutaneous reactive unit (S) consists of lobules (L) and septae (Sep). A fourth unit is the appendages (A; hair and sebaceous glands are the only appendages shown). HF, hair follicle.

 

Superficial Vascular Plexus:

 

  • Provides nutrients, oxygen, and temperature control.
  • Superficial plexus controls blood flow for heat regulation.

 

The location of the papillary and reticular layers of the dermis are depicted in the image below.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Understand the characteristics and contents of each layer of the epidermis, and recognize the location of various structures within the skin layers, such as the Odland bodies and the superficial vascular plexus.

 

Ref: Rooks Textbook of Dermatology- 9th Edition: Volume 1 Chapter 2, Page No 2.6, 2.7, 2.41

choices.text: Stratum Corneum, Stratum Spinosum, Stratum Granulosum, Stratum Basale
Stratum Corneum, Stratum Granulosum, Stratum Spinosum, Stratum Basale
Stratum Basale, Stratum Spinosum, Stratum Granulosum, Stratum Corneum
Stratum Basale, Stratum Granulosum, Stratum Spinosum, Stratum Corneum

questions.text: Which is the Correct Order of Layers of Epidermis from Deep to Superficial?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Stratum Basale, Stratum Spinosum, Stratum Granulosum, Stratum Corneum

 

Explanation:

 

From deep to superficial, the layers of the epidermis are as follows:

 

  • Stratum Basale
  • Stratum Spinosum
  • Stratum Granulosum
  • Stratum Lucidum
  • Stratum corneum

 

 

  • Stratum lucidum found in thick skin (palms, soles), between corneum and granulosum.
  • Epidermis is superficial, keratinized, stratified, squamous epithelium.
  • Epidermis is avascular, relies on dermis for nutrition through dermoepidermal junction.
  • Skin thickness varies: thinnest on eyelids, thickest on palms and soles.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Recognize the correct sequence of the epidermal layers from the deepest to the most superficial as Stratum Basale, Stratum Spinosum, Stratum Granulosum, and Stratum Corneum to understand the process of keratinocyte maturation and migration.

 

Ref: Rooks Textbook of Dermatology- 9th Edition: Volume 1 Chapter 2, Page No 2.5

questions.text: A 3-Year-Old Female Child presented with Skin Papules. You suspect it to be Langerhans Cell Histiocytosis (LCH). Which of the following is Most Specific Marker of Langerhans Cells?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) CD 207

 

Option C. CD207, also known as Langerin, is a type II transmembrane C-type lectin that is specifically expressed in Langerhans cells, which are specialized dendritic cells of the skin and mucosa. 

Langerhans cells are dendritic cells seen in the stratum spinosum.

The presence of CD207/Langerin is a key diagnostic feature in Langerhans cell histiocytosis.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. CD1a –

 

  • CD1a is a marker that is indeed expressed on Langerhans cells and can be used to identify them.

  • However, it is not as specific as CD207 for Langerhans cells because CD1a can also be expressed on some other dendritic cells.

 

Option B. CD3 –

 

  • This is a T-cell marker, and while Langerhans cells are part of the immune system, they are not T-cells, so CD3 would not be the right marker for identifying them.

 

Option D. CD68 –

 

  • CD68 is a marker for macrophages and other cells of the monocyte lineage.

  • While Langerhans cells are related to macrophages and dendritic cells, CD68 is not specific for Langerhans cells.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Identify CD207 (Langerin) as the most specific marker for Langerhans cells, which is crucial for the diagnosis of Langerhans cell histiocytosis.

 

Ref: Rooks Textbook of Dermatology- 9th Edition: Volume 1 Chapter 2, Page No 2.4

questions.text: What is the location of Meissner’s Corpuscles in Skin?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Papillary Dermis

 

Option C. Papillary Dermis –

 

  • This is the uppermost layer of the dermis, located just below the epidermis.
  • It is rich in small blood vessels and contains a number of sensory receptors, including Meissner's corpuscles.
  • Meissner’s corpuscles are responsible for sensitivity to light touch.
  • They are concentrated predominantly over glabrous (non-hair bearing) like fingertips & lips

 

 

https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:WVSOM_Meissner's_corpuslce.JPG

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Stratum Lucidum –

 

  • This is a thin, clear layer of dead skin cells in the epidermis named for its translucent appearance under a microscope.
  • It is found only in areas of thick skin, such as the palms of the hands and soles of the feet. Meissner’s corpuscles are not located in this layer.

 

Option B. Stratum Basale –

 

  • This is the deepest layer of the five layers of the epidermis, where cells divide and begin their journey to the surface.
  • Meissner’s corpuscles are not located in this layer.

 

Option D. Reticular Dermis –

 

  • This is the deeper layer of the dermis, beneath the papillary dermis, composed of dense irregular connective tissue featuring collagen and elastic fibers.
  • Meissner’s corpuscles are not found in this layer as they are associated with the more superficial papillary layer.

 

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Recognize that Meissner’s corpuscles are located in the papillary dermis of the skin, where they function as mechanoreceptors for light touch.

 

Ref: Andrew’s disease of the skin: Clinical dermatology- 11th edition page 8

Ganong’s review of medical physiology 25th edition pages no: 159-163

Ganong’s review of medical physiology 26th edition pages no: 158

choices.text: They connect Keratinocytes in the Epidermis of the Skin.
Acantholysis is Loss of Cohesion between Keratinocytes.
Pemphigus Vulgaris has Antibodies directed against Desmoglein.
They cannot resist Mechanical Stress as they are Weakly Adhesive.

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding Desmosomes is FALSE?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) They cannot resist Mechanical Stress as they are Weakly Adhesive.

 

Option D: Due to their strong adhesiveness, they can withstand mechanical stress. Desmoglein (Dsg), Desmocollin (Dsc), and DesmoPlakin are some of the proteins found in desmosomes (Dp).

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Keratinocytes in the skin's epidermis are connected by desmosomes, also known as macula adherens. It is a cell structure designed specifically for adhesion between cells.

 

 

Option B: Acantholysis can result from the separation of keratinocytes caused by the loss of any one protein.

 

 

Option C: Pemphigus vulgaris is an autoimmune condition brought on by antibodies that target Desmoglein found in desmosomes.

 

  • Loss of desmosomes causes keratinocyte cohesion to break down (acantholysis), which leads to blister formation.
  • Diseases of the skin and the heart can result from desmosome dysfunction. The primary cause of arrhythmogenic right ventricular cardiomyopathy is mutations within the desmosomes (ARVC)

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Desmosomes are strong adhesive junctions crucial for maintaining the structural integrity of tissues subjected to mechanical stress, and they play a critical role in connecting keratinocytes within the epidermis.

 

Ref: Rooks Textbook of Dermatology- 9th Edition: Volume 1 Chapter 2, Page No 2.2

choices.text: Hemidesmosomal Plaque components include BPAg1/BP230 Plectin
The Major Component of Lamina Densa is Collagen IV
Type VII Collagen is the Major Component of Anchoring Fibrils
Pemphigus Vulgaris has Antibodies against Hemidesmosomes

questions.text: Identify the INCORRECT statement regarding Dermoepidermal Junction?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Pemphigus Vulgaris has Antibodies against Hemidesmosomes

 

Option D: Bullous Pemphigoid has antibodies against Hemidesmosomes, not Pemphigus vulgaris.

 

Pemphigus vulgaris involves antibodies that attack desmoglein, a component of desmosomes, leading to the loss of cell-cell adhesion among keratinocytes, not an attack on hemidesmosomes.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Hemidesmosomal plaque components include BPAg1/BP230 Plectin

 

Hemidesmosome connects the basal cell layer to the Dermo Epidermal Junction (DEJ) or Basement Membrane Zone (BMZ). Hemidesmosomal plaques include various proteins, among which BPAG1 (also known as BP230) and plectin are critical components that help in the attachment of the intracellular keratin cytoskeleton to the hemidesmosome.

 

 

Image depicting structure of DEJ / BMZ

 

Option B.The lamina densa, part of the basement membrane

 

The lamina densa is an electron dense layer present in the dermo epidermal junction & this is rich in type IV collagen, which forms a dense network providing structural support to the dermoepidermal junction.

 

Components of lamina densa:

 

  • Collagen type IV
  • Laminin
  • BM-40
  • SPARC
  • Perlecan

 

Option C: Type VII collagen is the major component of anchoring fibrils that extend from the lamina densa into the underlying dermis to stabilize the attachment of the epidermis to the dermis in the dermo epidermal junction.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Pemphigus vulgaris is associated with autoantibodies against desmoglein in desmosomes, not hemidesmosomes, and understand the key components and functions of the dermoepidermal junction.

 

Ref: Rooks Textbook of Dermatology- 9th Edition: Volume 1 Chapter 2, Page No 2.20-2.21

questions.text: What is the Ratio of Type I to III Collagen in Adult Human Skin?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 8:1

 

Explanation:

 

Type I collagen is the most abundant collagen in the adult human dermis, comprising about 80% of the total collagen content, while type III collagen makes up about 15%. This gives a ratio of approximately 8:1 for type I to type III collagen in adult human skin.

 

  • Type I collagen is the most abundant collagen in the human dermis.
  • Type III collagen predominates in human skin during embryonic development.
  • During the early postnatal period, the synthesis of type I collagen accelerates.
  • As a result, the ratio of type I to type III collagen in adult human skin becomes approximately 8:1.
  • Type III collagen is most prominent in vascular connective tissues, the gastro-intestinal tract, and the uterus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Understand that in adult human skin, the ratio of type I to type III collagen is approximately 8:1, signifying the dominance of type I collagen in the dermal structure.

 

Ref: Rooks Textbook of Dermatology- 9th Edition: Volume 1 Chapter 2, Page No 2.26-2.28

questions.text: What is the Type of Connective Tissue present in the Area marked by the Black Arrow in the given image?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Dense Irregular

 

Explanation:

READ THE QUESTION CAREFULLY IN EXAMS: EXAMINER IS ASKING ABOUT BLACK ARROW , NOT YELLOW ARROW.

The area marked with the black arrow is the Reticular Dermis. It is made up of Dense Irregular Connective Tissue.

The area marked with the yellow arrow is the Papillary Dermis. It is made of loose areolar connective tissue.

 

Dermis (precisely Reticular dermis) is made up of Dense Irregular Connective Tissue.

 

Irregular connective tissue is characterized by collagen fibers that are randomly oriented in multiple directions.

 

Irregular connective tissue is of three types: Loose, Dense & Adipose.

 

Dense connective tissue can be found in areas where unsheathed organs are protected and where there is significant mechanical stress.

 

  • This arrangement of fibers provides strength and elasticity in multiple directions, allowing the skin to resist tearing.

 

Function: Provides structural integrity and support for the skin.

 

Dense Connective Tissue:

 

  • It typically exists in the Reticular Dermis.

  • Muscle and nerve sheaths made of the superficial connective tissue

  • Adventitia of large vessels

  • Capsules of various organs & glands (e.g.: testis sclera, periosteum, perichondrium)

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Ref: Rooks textbook of dermatology- 9th Edition: Volume 1 Chapter 2, Page no 2.34

https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Epidermis-delimited.JPG

choices.text: Parakeratosis is seen in Psoriasis
Acantholysis is seen in Bullous Pemphigoid
Spongiosis is seen in Acute Eczema
Acanthosis is the thickening of Stratum Spinosum

questions.text: Identify the FALSE statement among the following?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Acantholysis is seen in Bullous Pemphigoid

 

Option B: Bullous pemphigoid which is a subepidermal blistering  disorder, does NOT exhibit acantholysis.

 

  • Acantholysis is the breakdown of intercellular connections, such as desmosomes, which causes keratinocytes to become less cohesive.
  • Acantholytic cells/Tzanck cells are Circular, Prominent Nucleus with Peri-nuclear Halo

            ​​​​​​​    ​​​​​​​    ​​​​​​​    

 

 

Acantholysis is classified as -

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Actinic keratosis and psoriasis frequently exhibit parakeratosis, which is suggested by nucleated stratum corneum.

 

  • The term "parakeratosis" describes an abnormal keratinization process in which basal layer cells divide quickly, reaching the stratum corneum faster and failing to shed their nuclei.
  • As a result, the nucleated stratum corneum is observed on histopathology.

 

Parakeratosis (nucleated stratum corneum) can be seen in the below image pointed by black arrows.

 

 

Option C: Spongiosis is the characteristic histopathological feature of acute eczema

Intercellular edema involving the stratum spinosum is characteristic of spongiosis.

 

 

Option D: Acanthosis is characterised by an increase in the number of stratum spinosum cells, leading to its increased thickness. Other histological changes like Hypergranulosis, Hyperkeratosis, and Papillomatosis are frequently present in patients with acanthosis. It appears in Lupus Vulgaris, Verruca Vulgaris, and Chronic Eczema.

 

Below is an illustration of acanthosis. Notice the increased thickness of the Malpighian layer & elongated rete ridges.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Acantholysis is a feature of Pemphigus Vulgaris, not Bullous Pemphigoid, while parakeratosis is a hallmark of psoriasis, spongiosis is characteristic of acute eczema, and acanthosis indicates the thickening of the stratum spinosum.

 

Ref: Rooks Textbook of Dermatology- 9th Edition: Volume 1 Chapter 3, Page No 3.33, 3.38

https://dermnetnz.org/topics/eczema-pathology

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Spongiotic_dermatitis_(2)_Dyshidrotic.JPG

https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Micrograph_of_early_actinic_keratosis_with_parakeratosis.jpg

questions.text: Dyskeratosis can be seen in which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) All of the above

 

Explanation:

 

Dyskeratosis refers to the premature keratinization of individual cells or groups of cells within the epidermal layer and is characterised by nuclear pyknosis & condensation of the cytoplasm of keratinocytes.

 

This can occur in:

 

Option A: Malignant lesion

 

  • Squamous Cell Carcinoma

 

Option B: Premalignant lesions

 

  • Bowens disease (Squamous Cell Carcinoma in situ)
  • Paget’s disease
  • Solar keratosis

 

Option C: Benign conditions

 

  • Darier disease
  • Hailey hailey disease

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Dyskeratosis is a histological feature that can be seen in a variety of skin conditions including Squamous Cell Carcinoma, Bowen's disease, and Darier's disease.

 

Ref: Rooks Textbook of Dermatology- 9th Edition: Volume 1 Chapter 3, Page No 3.36-37

choices.text: Spongiform Pustules of Kogoj- Lichen Planus
Papillary Tip Microabscess- Dermatitis Herpetiformis

questions.text: Identify the WRONG match among the following Micro Abscesses & the associated Diseases?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Spongiform Pustules of Kogoj- Lichen Planus

 

Option B: This is wrong match, because Spongiform pustules of Kogoj, which are a collection of neutrophils are associated with Psoriasis, not Lichen Planus.

 

 

A microabscess is small cavity in the epidermis or dermis formed by collections of inflammatory cells.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Munro's microabscesses are collections of neutrophils in the stratum corneum and are indeed characteristic of Psoriasis.

 

Option C. Pautrier's microabscesses are collections of lymphocytes within the epidermis and are a diagnostic histological feature of Mycosis Fungoides, a type of cutaneous T-cell lymphoma.

 

 

Pautrier's microabscesses

 

Option D. Papillary tip microabscesses, which are collections of neutrophils at the tips of dermal papillae, are characteristic of Dermatitis Herpetiformis.

 

 

Some types of microabscess and their examples are given below.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Spongiform pustules of Kogoj is indicative of Psoriasis, not Lichen Planus.

 

Ref: Rooks Textbook of Dermatology- 9th Edition: Volume 1 Chapter 3, 50 Page No 3.38, 50.6

choices.text: Stratum Basale & Stratum Spinosum
Stratum Basale & Stratum Granulosum
Stratum Spinosum & Stratum Basale
Stratum Basale & Stratum Basale

questions.text: Merkel cells & Melanocytes are located in ____________ & _____________ layers in the epidermis respectively. Fill in the blanks.
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Stratum Basale & Stratum Basale

 

Explanation:

 

Option D. Merkel cells are found in the stratum basale layer of the epidermis, which is the deepest layer of the epidermis and provides the foundation for the skin's outer layer. Similarly, melanocytes, which are responsible for pigment production, are also located in the stratum basale

 

 

 

Merkel cells (Touch cells or Haascheiben cells or Merkel-Ranvier cells or tactile epithelial cells) are oval shaped mechanoreceptors essential for light touch sensation & are abundant in the highly sensitive areas of the skin like fingertips & synapse with somatosensory afferent nerve fibres.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Both Merkel cells and melanocytes are located in the stratum basale layer of the epidermis.

 

Ref: Ganong’s Review of Medical Physiology 25th Edition Pages No: 159-163

Ganong’s Review of Medical Physiology 26th Edition Pages no: 158

questions.text: Retention of Nuclei in Cells of Stratum Corneum is known as:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Parakeratosis

 

Option B: Parakeratosis is defined as the retention of nuclei in the cells of the stratum corneum as pointed by the arrows in the image below.

 

 

The presence of these nuclei indicates a rapid turnover of epidermal cells, where keratinocytes do not have enough time to lose their nuclei before reaching the outermost layer of the skin. It is commonly seen in psoriasis & actinic keratosis.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Hyperkeratosis:

 

  • Hyperkeratosis refers to the thickening of the stratum corneum, this is observed in Psoriasis, Lichen Planus, & Icthyosis.
  • It does not necessarily imply the retention of nuclei.

 

Option C. Orthokeratosis:

 

  • It is the term used to describe a normal stratum corneum where cells do not retain their nuclei.
  • It is the opposite of parakeratosis.

 

Option D. Dyskeratosis:

 

  • This refers to the abnormal formation or premature keratinization of individual cells or groups of cells below the stratum granulosum.
  • It is a sign of cellular disorder and disruption in the normal maturation process of keratinocytes.

  • Examples: Darier Disease, Bowen Disease, Squamous Cell Carcinoma

     

Educational Objective:

 

  • Parakeratosis is characterized by the retention of nuclei in the cells of the stratum corneum, distinguishing it from hyperkeratosis (thickening), orthokeratosis (normal), and dyskeratosis (abnormal keratinization).

 

Ref: Rooks Textbook of Dermatology- 9th Edition: Volume 1 Chapter 3, Page No 3.38

questions.text: A 27-year-old male presents to the dermatology clinic with recurrent skin blisters. On examination, superficial skin erosions with clear fluid-filled blisters are observed on his trunk and limbs. Microscopic examination of a skin biopsy shows disruption between epidermal cells, but the basement membrane remains intact. The physician suspects a disorder affecting desmosomes. Desmosomes are cell junctions primarily responsible for connecting which of the following?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Keratinocytes.

 

Option A: Desmosomes are specialized cell junctions that provide strong adhesive connections primarily between keratinocytes as shown in the image below. 

 

 

These cells make up the majority of cells in the epidermis. The desmosomal connections between keratinocytes provide the skin with its structural integrity, making it resistant to mechanical stresses.

Note - Desmosomes are located in Stratum Spinosum. Desmosomes are Intra-epidermal & intercellular Connections. Pemphigus Group of diseases are characterized by antibodies that are targeted against Desmosomes.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Melanocytes:

 

  • Melanocytes are responsible for producing melanin, the pigment that gives color to the Skin, Hair, and Eyes.
  • While they are located in the basal layer of the epidermis, they are not primarily connected by desmosomes.

 

Option C. Dermis & Epidermis:

 

  • The connection between the dermis and epidermis is facilitated by the basement membrane, and not by desmosomes.
  • Hemidesmosomes, another type of cell junction, anchor epidermal cells to the underlying dermal layer.

 

Option D. Langerhans cells: Langerhans cells are specialized immune cells found in the skin as shown in the image below.

 

 

LC = Langerhans Cells

 

Their primary function is antigen presentation. They are not primarily connected by desmosomes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Desmosomes are specialized cell junctions that primarily provide strong adhesive connections between keratinocytes in the epidermis, ensuring skin's structural integrity.

 

Ref: Fitzpatrick’s Textbook of Dermatology- 9th Edition: Volume 1 Page No 22, 23, 63.

questions.text: A 35-year-old female presents to the dermatology clinic with an Itchy Rash on her Arms and Legs. On examination, Erythematous Patches with oozing are noted. A Skin Biopsy is performed, which shows Intercellular Edema in the Epidermis. This histological feature is most commonly associated with which Layer of the Epidermis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Stratum Spinosum.

 

Option A:

 

  • Spongiosis refers to the intercellular edema (accumulation of fluid) between keratinocytes, primarily seen in the stratum spinosum layer of the epidermis as shown in the image below.

 

 

Spongiosis:

 

  • Accumulation of fluid in the epidermis is manifested by white space between the keratinocytes.
  • This finding is frequently observed in conditions like eczema and other inflammatory skin disorders.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Stratum Basale:

 

  • This is the deepest layer of the epidermis, consisting of a single layer of columnar or cuboidal basal cells.
  • It's primarily responsible for the generation of new keratinocytes.

 

Option C. Stratum Corneum:

 

  • This is the outermost layer of the epidermis, composed of dead, flattened keratinocytes known as corneocytes.
  • These cells lack nuclei and are filled with keratin, providing a barrier function to the skin.

 

Option D. Stratum Granulosum:

 

  • This layer is located beneath the stratum corneum and consists of keratinocytes that are undergoing terminal differentiation.
  • These cells contain keratohyaline granules which can be seen in the image below, which contribute to the formation of the skin's barrier function.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Spongiosis, which refers to intercellular edema in the epidermis, is primarily associated with the stratum spinosum layer.

 

Ref: Fitzpatrick’s Textbook of Dermatology- 9th Edition: Volume 1 Page No 13, 22

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents to the clinic with flaccid bullae on his trunk and oral mucosa. The blisters rupture easily upon minor trauma. A skin biopsy is taken and shows intraepidermal blisters with loss of connections between epidermal cells. What is the primary structure affected in this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Intercellular Substance

 

Option D: Intercellular Substance:

 

  • Acantholysis is due to the destruction or loss of cohesion of the intercellular substance, causing the epidermal cells to separate from one another.
  • This leads to the formation of intraepidermal blisters, as seen in conditions like pemphigus vulgaris.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Epidermis:

 

  • While acantholysis manifests in the epidermis, the entire layer isn’t destroyed.
  • Instead, acantholysis is characterized by a loss of cohesion between individual epidermal cells, specifically within the intercellular substance.

 

Option B. Dermis:

 

  • The dermis is the layer beneath the epidermis and provides support to the epidermis.
  • Acantholysis is primarily an epidermal process, and the dermis remains unaffected.

 

Option C. Basement membrane:

 

  • The basement membrane acts as a barrier between the epidermis and dermis, supporting the epidermal cells and anchoring them to the dermis.
  • In acantholysis, the basement membrane remains intact.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Acantholysis is primarily due to the loss of cohesion within the intercellular substance of the epidermis, leading to intraepidermal blistering.

 

Ref: Fitzpatrick’s Textbook of Dermatology- 9th Edition: Volume 1 Page No 918

questions.text: A 30-year-old female patient presents with concerns about patchy skin pigmentation, which has become more pronounced after her recent beach vacation. A biopsy of the affected skin is likely to show increased activity in which layer of the epidermis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Stratum Basale

 

Option B: Melanocytes are found in the stratum basale, the deepest layer of the epidermis as shown in the image below.

 

 

  • They produce melanin, which gives skin its color and protects against UV radiation.
  • The increased pigmentation observed in the patient is due to the activity of melanocytes in this layer.

 

Option A. Stratum Spinosum:

 

  • This layer is known for its spiny appearance due to desmosomal connections between keratinocytes.
  • While melanin can be transferred to keratinocytes here, melanocytes themselves are not located in this layer.

 

Option C. Stratum Corneum:

 

  • This is the outermost layer of the skin, composed of dead keratinocytes that have migrated from lower layers.
  • It does not contain melanocytes.

 

Option D. Stratum Granulosum:

 

  • This layer contains keratinocytes that are in the process of keratinization, preparing to move up to the stratum corneum.
  • It does not house melanocytes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Melanocytes, the cells responsible for pigment production, are in the Stratum Basale of the epidermis.

 

Ref: Fitzpatrick’s Textbook of Dermatology- 9th Edition: Volume 1 Page No 7

questions.text: A 55-year-old male with diabetes mellitus comes to the clinic complaining of decreased sensation in his fingertips. On examination, Rapidly adapting receptors sensitive to changes in light touch & texture discrimination are diminished. Vibration sense was intact. These findings could be attributed to the dysfunction of which tactile receptors primarily located in the skin?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Papillary Dermis.

 

Option C: The clinical findings suggest a dysfunction of the rapidly adapting receptors, which are primarily responsible for sensing light touch and textural changes.

 

  • These receptors are the Meissner's corpuscles, located in the papillary dermis of the skin as shown in the image below, particularly concentrated in the fingertips.

 

 

Diabetes mellitus can lead to peripheral neuropathy, which often affects these sensory receptors.

 

 

Merkel cells versus Meissner’s corpuscles:

 

 

 

Explanation:

 

Options A and B. The Stratum Spinosum and Stratum Basale, respectively, are Layers of the epidermis that do not contain these sensory receptors.

 

  • The stratum spinosum is known for its role in providing strength and flexibility to the skin, while the stratum basale is the deepest layer of the epidermis responsible for generating new skin cells.

 

Option D. The Reticular dermis is the deeper layer of the dermis that provides structural support to the skin and has Pacinian corpuscles which detect deep pressure and vibration.

 

  • Vibration sense is normal as mentioned in the question, so reticular dermis is ruled out

 

 

Pacinian corpuscles: Depicted in the above image.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The rapidly adapting receptors sensitive to changes in light touch and texture discrimination, which are diminished in a patient with diabetes mellitus presenting with decreased fingertip sensation, are Meissner's corpuscles located in the papillary dermis.

 

Ref: Fitzpatrick’s Textbook of Dermatology- 9th Edition: Volume 1 Page No 7

questions.text: A 40-year-old female presents with concerns about premature skin aging. On examination, you note reduced skin elasticity and increased laxity. You explain that these changes are often related to alterations in the dermal layer of the skin where collagen fibers provide structural support. Which type of collagen, the most abundant in the human dermis, is primarily responsible for the strength and resiliency of this layer?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Type I

 

Option A: The most abundant form of collagen in the dermis is Type I collagen, which provides tensile strength and resistance to force, and is a major structural component of the skin, bone, tendons, and ligaments.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Type II collagen

 

  • It is mainly found in cartilage and is not a significant component of the skin's dermis.
  • It provides cartilage with its tensile strength and resistance to pressure.

 

Option C. Type III collagen

 

  • This is associated with reticulate fibers, commonly found alongside Type I collagen in the dermis, but it is not as abundant as Type I.
  • It is also found in blood vessels and tissues with elastic properties.

 

Option D. Type IV collagen is a type of collagen found in the basal lamina (Lamina Densa) as shown in the image below.

 

 

The layer of the extracellular matrix on which epithelial cells sit and is not present in the dermis in significant amounts. It is important for filtration and is found in the basement membranes of tissues.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Type I collagen is the most abundant collagen in the dermis, providing structural support and skin integrity.

 

Ref: Rooks Textbook of Dermatology- 9th Edition: Volume 1 Chapter 2, Page No 2.26-2.28

choices.text: Both Assertion and reason are true & reason is the correct explanation of assertion
Both assertion and reason are true & reason is NOT the correct explanation of assertion
Assertion is correct & reason is false
Assertion is false & reason is true

questions.text:
A 52-year-old patient presents with flaccid blisters on the trunk and proximal extremities. Skin biopsy shows intraepidermal blistering with acantholytic cells. Direct immunofluorescence of the skin reveals intercellular IgG deposits within the epidermis. Below is the Assertion and Reason related to this case scenario, mark the option which correctly describes the underlying pathology of this condition?

 

Assertion: Desmosomes are damaged in pemphigus.

 

Reason: Pemphigus has autoimmunity against desmoglein.
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Both Assertion and reason are true & reason is the correct explanation of assertion

 

Option A. Pemphigus is characterized by the presence of autoantibodies against Desmoglein, which is a key component of desmosomes, leading to their disruption and consequent intraepidermal blistering. This option is correct.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. The assertion is correct, but in this case, the reason is directly related to the assertion and is the correct explanation.

 

Option C. Both the assertion and the reason are true, making this option incorrect.

 

Option D. Both the assertion and the reason are true, so this option is incorrect.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The learner should recognize that in pemphigus, autoantibodies target Desmoglein, a constituent of desmosomes, leading to their damage and resulting in the clinical manifestation of intraepidermal blisters.

 

Ref:  Fitzpatrick’s Textbook of Dermatology- 9th Edition: Volume 1 Page No 915

questions.text: A 46-year-old patient with a history of sun exposure presents with a suspicious pigmented lesion on her upper back. A biopsy is performed, and immunohistochemical staining is ordered to determine the cell type of origin. Which of the following markers is NOT typically used to identify melanocytes in the evaluation of this lesion?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Cytokeratin 20

 

Option D: Cytokeratin 20 is not typically expressed in melanocytes. Instead, it is a marker more commonly associated with epithelial cells, and it is used as an immunohistochemical marker in the diagnosis of carcinomas, such as Merkel cell carcinoma.

 

  • This is the correct answer because it is not a marker for melanocytes.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. HMB 45 (Human Melanoma Black -45)

 

  • It is an antibody that reacts against an antigen present in melanocytes, used as a marker in identifying melanomas.

 

Option B. S 100

 

  • It is a protein found in cells derived from the neural crest (melanocytes).  It is a marker for Langerhans cells also.
  • Neuroectodermal Markers: S 100, HMB 45, Melan A.

 

Option C. Melan A

 

  • It is another marker used in the identification of melanocytes and is also used in the diagnosis of melanoma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Cytokeratin 20 is not a marker for melanocytes and recognize the use of HMB 45, S 100, and Melan A as immunohistochemical stains for the identification of melanocytes and melanoma.

 

Ref: Fitzpatrick’s Textbook of Dermatology- 9th Edition: Volume 1 Page No 20, 1920

choices.text: Basal & Spinous Cells
Corneum & Granular Layer
Granular & Spinous Layer
Only Spinous Layer

questions.text: A patient presents with flaccid bullae and erosions on the skin. Histopathological examination reveals intraepidermal blistering and acantholysis within the epidermis. Direct immunofluorescence shows IgG antibodies against cell surface antigens in the skin. These clinical findings suggest a diagnosis of pemphigus vulgaris, which is characterized by autoantibodies against Desmogleins — components of desmosomes that are critical for cell-cell adhesion within the epidermis, particularly affecting the Malpighian layer. Which among the below options constitutes the Malpighian layer?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Basal & Spinous Cells

 

Option A.

 

  • The Malpighian layer, also known as the Malpighian stratum, includes the basal cell layer (stratum basale) and the spinous layer (stratum spinosum).

 

 

  • This is where keratinocytes are most active in proliferation and where desmosomes are vital for cell adhesion, which can be disrupted in conditions such as pemphigus vulgaris.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Corneum & Granular Layer:

 

  • These layers are above the Malpighian layer. The stratum corneum is the outermost layer composed of dead keratinocytes, while the stratum granulosum contains keratohyalin granules that lead to keratinization.
  • They are not typically involved in acantholysis seen in pemphigus vulgaris.

 

Option C. Granular & Spinous Layer:

 

  • Although the spinous layer is part of the Malpighian stratum, the granular layer is not.
  • It is the layer just superficial to the Malpighian layer and plays a role in keratin production, not cell adhesion.

 

Option D. Only Spinous Layer:

 

  • This is partially correct, as the spinous layer is a component of the Malpighian layer; however, it does not include the basal layer which is also a key part of the Malpighian stratum.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The Malpighian layer of the epidermis includes the stratum basale and stratum spinosum.
  • These layers are crucial for keratinocyte adhesion via desmosomes, which can be disrupted in autoimmune conditions such as pemphigus vulgaris, leading to acantholysis and blistering.

 

Ref: Rooks Textbook of Dermatology- 9th Edition: Volume 1 Chapter 2, Page No 2.5
